MORGAN'S CASE The excitement on the
subject OF the o' chile abduction OF Morgan seems
to be every day growing stronger and stronger IN
the western part oil the Sae. he newspapers
Of thai quarter are full OF articles the subject yet
The citizens complain the public journals are cow
atdly and pusillanmous in the exp esxion of just
indignation on the occasion A meeting of the in
habitants of the town OF Seneca has been held
take into consideration "ths late violation Of the
laws and outrages the rights of an American
citizen in the person OF William Morgan. An ad
dress and resolutions were drafted and have been
published The address states an outrage OF the
most daring kind had been committed that the
courts of law had been in vain appealed to for pun
ishment OF the offenders; that secret and invis.


ble power had controlled the course of justice, and
tina, it was time for every citizen 10 look to his own
safety. The resolutions were to this purport That
all secret associations dangerous 20 freedom, and
the powerful one of freemasons especially SO that
the meeting will not vote Tor treemaons tor any OF
fee whatever; that the sentence pronounced up
on those who carried off Morgan is an insult to an
enlightened peoples that the meeting will petition
for a law to prevent the like outrages 10 tuturc;
that The silence of the public journals the subject


is alarming, and that the meeting will take no news
papers which do not publish the facts and public
proceedings relative TO the late outrage. and will dis
courage much as possible their circulation.
committee was appointed to correspond and concert
measures with other committees on this subject
and 10 open subscription defrsy the expenses OF
further investigation OF This affair.


W 7. Post.


.Morgan--anothpr report.-We have been in


formed, very respectable authority, says the AL
bany Argus Of Tuesday, that affdavi,s ere now in
this city, and will be published n the course Of the
present week, which the following facts viz.
that Morgan was carried to the British territory by
the persons who seized him in this state that he
was received there and confined in Fort George !;
that he underwent trial, and was convicted, with
the assent, however, Of only part OF the pretended
jury; and that he was executed, according to his
sentence. by young Indian This story is current
here. We confess that it seems to Us highly i'm
probable. No such thing. We should think, could
be transacted in British post, occupied By British
troops, and in the midst Of the town Of Newark. Il

Whose birth place we ow not, and seek rot 70 know,

lshe course of its music they flow.

Like Ivory baiks which fairy hath made

he sunshine ike Hope, in its noontide hour slnmbers

who ca tell me whence hat glad river has risen

ratiop should be observed. Every one knows that
kid, lamb, calf or even puppy or kitten, can
not thrive if squeezed or ,umbled about An infant
is certainly more easily hurt. Yet in addition to
this horrid dressing, his cluihes are often tight


that he irets and roars though he cannot give words
~ his complaints. Pins should never be used 10
infants clothes; and every thing should be so loose


ly tied that one might get two fingers between it
and that part where it is fixed. Bsndages round the
he ad should be strictly forbidden. Many instances
Of idiotsm, fits and deformity. are owing to tight
bandages In laying child to sleep, he should be
laid on the right side ofener than the leh bot
twice 10 four and twenty hours at least he should be
changed TO the left side Laying him on his back
when he is awake is enough OF that posture, in
which he can alone move his legs and arms with
freedom Infants are sometimes very restless al
night, ard il is generally owing either to examining
them with heavy supper. tight night clothes, or
being overaeated by too many blankets Il may al


so proceed from putting them 10 sleep too early He
should be KEEP, awake until the family going to
rest and the house free from noise. Undressing
him and baihI.g him will weary and dispose him TO
sleep. and universal stiffness will promote it, Never
let any thing hui the prescription oil physician, if
sickness, TEMPT you to give him wine, spirits, any
drug to make him sleep. Milk and water, whey
or thin Cruel, is he only fiji liquor for little ones
even when they can run about The more simple
and light Their diet, The more they will thrive Such
food will keep lhei, body regular and they cannot
be long we'll if you neglect that essential point


When opeuing medicine must be given to supply
the defect Of nature little mamma magnesa is
safest. careful and dlligent mother will attend
to tht Sc particulars, keeping all her children under
her own eye, and giving them lessons OF more va
lue than gad or itwels, in the time that lazy and
gsddlng gossps are looking at their fingers, or CIV

Follow him. you have heart to do it,
ss he staggers along, now and then licking the
ground, ill he reaches his once peaceful home


He's coming" cry the little innocenis, as they
look through the window; but 's not the cry of Joy
that welcomes the kind parent as he approaches his
lender iamily-ah, no tits tht cry Of ear--of hor-
See them flee from him as from monster
lock at the broken hearted mother, as she takes
up her affrighted boy and bathes him with her
tears. "Ab," says she 10 her children, "your tath
lnyed you--once he loved me he was a
kind husband and proydent father but now we
are torsaken your little tender feet feel the nip
p.ng irost; your bodies shiver with the cold your
Ia cred clothes are falling from you, and have no
new ones 10 give, you are hungry, but have no
bread Tor you; the necessaies OF lite your father
wa, wort 10 bring home to heer our hearts are
now changed for the rum bottle, which some demon
had furnished him with, perhaps as the reward OF
his days labor--O cruel employer come and be.
hold The fruits oil your iniquy; see The miseres rn
tailed upon he w,etched mother and her worse than
fatherless chi dren b, your lhirst for gain" Let
the imagination supply the remaining part OF the
awful Picture"

Railway.-The Stockbrldge Star says. that the
citizens OF Berkshire Mass will not wait tor the tar
dy movements OF the Massachusetts legislature, brs
will Immediately take measures to construct rail
road from the rich marble mountains in West
Slockbridge to the North River. They have no
fears about the of the enterprise. They
have calculated the expense, and are confident that
their cash will be pro6taby invested.


The length Of the railway between Stockton ami
Darlington, England, is twelve miles There ars
two coaches upon it, for the conveyance OF passan-
gers, each OF which twice a day between the
two towns. One of the coaches carries six inside,
and fifteen outside passengers, and performs the
Journey in one hour and half with the aid OF
single horse. The other coach carries forty pas
srngers, and is also drawn by one horse.

From the NJ Y. Commercial .adrertiser, Feb. 6.


THE MoRGAN CAsE-We learn from the Wes-
tern papers that mother convention has been held
at Lewiston, to discover, it possible, the fate of
Morgan. The Buffalo Patriot states that sufficient
evidence collected t. satisfy the convention thar
after Morgan had been kept few days at Fort Nj
agara, he was deliberately put to death at that place.


The Enquirer OF this morning gives another, and
more partic uar Version Of the story. on the author
ity Of a gentleman from Albany, who had read et-
ter from respectable gentleman Of Genesee, to one
OF our senators, who states names and places III re-
laon to the abduction Of Morgan, which iftrue, are
horrible,


"It is said he was carried across the frontier ins
to Canada by three persons, whose names are too
respectable TO hazard without strong proof; that
an application made to Brandt, an Indian CHIEF
and mason. to have Morgan conveyed to the North
West Coast but he refused to have any thing to do
with the affair. The persons then addressed them.
selves to masoDs 10 the British service, TO have
Morgan carried down the St. Lawrence and put on
board vessel; this was also declined; Morgan
was then confined. with his arms pinnned. IN the
Fort, and the gentlemen held some kind OF trial, in
which it was determined to put him to death and
that before day break they went TO Morgan and an-
nounced his fate, and he pleaded for light and
bible, together with an hours delay. The report
goes to state tina, they cut his throat and threw
his body n the river. Such is the account OF his
mysterious transaction, revesled by some one who
knew of the affair; and whether true not, letter
communicating the above, has been received by one
of senator's and it is added, that one OF The gen.
;lemen implicated has since given tokens of inssni-
ty. 1t Is, all round an extraordinary affair, and we
marvel why The heads ol the craft do not move
n it,


This story NAV be true, because all things are
possible - But we have some reasons for doubling
il. We have this morning had conversation with
British officer from Upper Canada He has recent
ly conversed with Captain Brandt-(a son OF the ce.
lebraed Brandt OF the revolution, aud highly res-
pectable man) who knows nothing about the affair
whatever Besides, il is not likely that he should,
as he does not reside at Fort George. but fifty miles
in the interior. Our informant also that
affairs are so situated at Fort George, that entrance
could not have been obtained for the purpose of
acting that or any other tragedy. Nor was II beliey-
ed in The neighbourhood of Fort George, that Nor
gan had ever been taken across the river, and the
whole matter was spoken very lightly OF among the


inhabitants there. A,the same time justice requires
US to admit that there is small coincidence be-
tween the above story and he testimony of Israel B.
Hail. given on The trial OF Sheldon and others al Ca
nandaigua 1t stated in the story above, that an at
empt was made at Fort George TO get some OF The
British officers to carry Morgan down hs 81 Law
renee, and put him on board British vessel. And
MIR. Hall testified that Cheeseboro said Morgan
was where Miller would not get hold OF him-tha
he avoided giving witness direct answers to his ques
ions, and witness thinks he said be guessed Nor
gan was OF might be board British ship :
There seems TO be no doubt of the fact that Nor
gan was traced 10 the buryng ground between Lew
ston and Fort Niagara; the carriage stopped there;
ard all afterwards is mystery. The ou ylng ground
is on the bank of the river, and within few hun
ded yards Of the Fort

Hhrrnan was travelling in the eastern part OF Eng
land ID becoming almos! destitute ot cash, he
objected considerable quantity OF mill dust, and
continued his Journey. Now came still evening
on" and Paddy ente,ed public house and called
Tor entertainment. During the evening he bus'ed
himself in tying his dust up in small papers, IN the
form Of powders On being lnterrogated by the
iandlady to know hot the papers contained, he re-
piled" Fla powthur. ma'am; for the purpose OF
killing fas.n The goodlady, whose house had been
so,ely besieged by these troublesome maranders,
was very anxious to obai" some OF the powders !;
and Paddy agreed for his lodging breakfast bitters
&c 10 furnish her with quantity sufficient to des-
troy all he f9s in it. H., accordingly was treated
with the greatest hospitality. and in The morning
(hay;ng left dozen or Of his powders,j he
slung his pack and with great sang trsd was about
to DEPART when his benevolent hostess called upon
him TO know in what manner she should apply The
| powder tPon me sowl, to be sure, was or the
| pon, of forgetting to give ye the directions Well,


then mind dive see, you must take the little era


chures by the nap o. the neck. and With leather
tickle their tails and when they open their mouths


10 laugh, Just throw in few grains OF the prwthur


and i, will be sure death forum III warrant ye-


Good morning ma'am!'

full articles.article:
Silent and lsk AS the source OF yon river,


Whose birth place we ow not, and seek rot 70 know,
Though wild as The fight OF the STAFF from yen quiver,


lshe course of its music they flow.
The lily hings DER its silver white blossom,


Like Ivory baiks which fairy hath made


tie rose o'er il bends with its beautiful bosom,


AS though iwere enamoured itself VI its shade.


he sunshine ike Hope, in its noontide hour slnmbers


On he stream, i loved the bright place OF $ rest
AID ras> song, the shells soft numbers


Had given to these atvis their sweetest and best.
The banks thai SUR ound Aower-dropt and sunny


There the first birth OF woes odoni-showers weep
There tho bee heaps his ealest treasure OF honey,


Or sinks in the depths o. the hatebeli 10 sleep.
Like prisoners ESCAPED during ght from their prison,


The waters Il ny gay heir spray 70 the sun
who ca tell me whence hat glad river has risen


Who say whepce II sprhss IN its beauty f-not one
Oh my het and ms song, which is asmy hearts flowing,


X, al thy fate il son aver for such is thine own
Md those I chief praise on thy music bestowing,


Who cares for the lips from whence issue the tone
Dark as its birth place 50 dark my spirit
Whence yet the sweet waters Of melody came,
lis the ng afiel course, not the source will inherit
The beauty and glory Of sunshine and fame
L. E. L.

ratiop should be observed. Every one knows that
kid, lamb, calf or even puppy or kitten, can
not thrive if squeezed or ,umbled about An infant
is certainly more easily hurt. Yet in addition to
this horrid dressing, his cluihes are often tight


that he irets and roars though he cannot give words
~ his complaints. Pins should never be used 10
infants clothes; and every thing should be so loose


ly tied that one might get two fingers between it
and that part where it is fixed. Bsndages round the
he ad should be strictly forbidden. Many instances
Of idiotsm, fits and deformity. are owing to tight
bandages In laying child to sleep, he should be
laid on the right side ofener than the leh bot
twice 10 four and twenty hours at least he should be
changed TO the left side Laying him on his back
when he is awake is enough OF that posture, in
which he can alone move his legs and arms with
freedom Infants are sometimes very restless al
night, ard il is generally owing either to examining
them with heavy supper. tight night clothes, or
being overaeated by too many blankets Il may al


so proceed from putting them 10 sleep too early He
should be KEEP, awake until the family going to
rest and the house free from noise. Undressing
him and baihI.g him will weary and dispose him TO
sleep. and universal stiffness will promote it, Never
let any thing hui the prescription oil physician, if
sickness, TEMPT you to give him wine, spirits, any
drug to make him sleep. Milk and water, whey
or thin Cruel, is he only fiji liquor for little ones
even when they can run about The more simple
and light Their diet, The more they will thrive Such
food will keep lhei, body regular and they cannot
be long we'll if you neglect that essential point


When opeuing medicine must be given to supply
the defect Of nature little mamma magnesa is
safest. careful and dlligent mother will attend
to tht Sc particulars, keeping all her children under
her own eye, and giving them lessons OF more va
lue than gad or itwels, in the time that lazy and
gsddlng gossps are looking at their fingers, or CIV


ing and hearing news Economist.

full articles.headline: THE TIppLER-
full articles.article:
Follow him. you have heart to do it,
ss he staggers along, now and then licking the
ground, ill he reaches his once peaceful home


He's coming" cry the little innocenis, as they
look through the window; but 's not the cry of Joy
that welcomes the kind parent as he approaches his
lender iamily-ah, no tits tht cry Of ear--of hor-
See them flee from him as from monster
lock at the broken hearted mother, as she takes
up her affrighted boy and bathes him with her
tears. "Ab," says she 10 her children, "your tath
lnyed you--once he loved me he was a
kind husband and proydent father but now we
are torsaken your little tender feet feel the nip
p.ng irost; your bodies shiver with the cold your
Ia cred clothes are falling from you, and have no
new ones 10 give, you are hungry, but have no
bread Tor you; the necessaies OF lite your father
wa, wort 10 bring home to heer our hearts are
now changed for the rum bottle, which some demon
had furnished him with, perhaps as the reward OF
his days labor--O cruel employer come and be.
hold The fruits oil your iniquy; see The miseres rn
tailed upon he w,etched mother and her worse than
fatherless chi dren b, your lhirst for gain" Let
the imagination supply the remaining part OF the
awful Picture"

full articles.headline: - o.D n---
full articles.article:
Railway.-The Stockbrldge Star says. that the
citizens OF Berkshire Mass will not wait tor the tar
dy movements OF the Massachusetts legislature, brs
will Immediately take measures to construct rail
road from the rich marble mountains in West
Slockbridge to the North River. They have no
fears about the of the enterprise. They
have calculated the expense, and are confident that
their cash will be pro6taby invested.


The length Of the railway between Stockton ami
Darlington, England, is twelve miles There ars
two coaches upon it, for the conveyance OF passan-
gers, each OF which twice a day between the
two towns. One of the coaches carries six inside,
and fifteen outside passengers, and performs the
Journey in one hour and half with the aid OF
single horse. The other coach carries forty pas
srngers, and is also drawn by one horse.

From the NJ Y. Commercial .adrertiser, Feb. 6.


THE MoRGAN CAsE-We learn from the Wes-
tern papers that mother convention has been held
at Lewiston, to discover, it possible, the fate of
Morgan. The Buffalo Patriot states that sufficient
evidence collected t. satisfy the convention thar
after Morgan had been kept few days at Fort Nj
agara, he was deliberately put to death at that place.


The Enquirer OF this morning gives another, and
more partic uar Version Of the story. on the author
ity Of a gentleman from Albany, who had read et-
ter from respectable gentleman Of Genesee, to one
OF our senators, who states names and places III re-
laon to the abduction Of Morgan, which iftrue, are
horrible,


"It is said he was carried across the frontier ins
to Canada by three persons, whose names are too
respectable TO hazard without strong proof; that
an application made to Brandt, an Indian CHIEF
and mason. to have Morgan conveyed to the North
West Coast but he refused to have any thing to do
with the affair. The persons then addressed them.
selves to masoDs 10 the British service, TO have
Morgan carried down the St. Lawrence and put on
board vessel; this was also declined; Morgan
was then confined. with his arms pinnned. IN the
Fort, and the gentlemen held some kind OF trial, in
which it was determined to put him to death and
that before day break they went TO Morgan and an-
nounced his fate, and he pleaded for light and
bible, together with an hours delay. The report
goes to state tina, they cut his throat and threw
his body n the river. Such is the account OF his
mysterious transaction, revesled by some one who
knew of the affair; and whether true not, letter
communicating the above, has been received by one
of senator's and it is added, that one OF The gen.
;lemen implicated has since given tokens of inssni-
ty. 1t Is, all round an extraordinary affair, and we
marvel why The heads ol the craft do not move
n it,


This story NAV be true, because all things are
possible - But we have some reasons for doubling
il. We have this morning had conversation with
British officer from Upper Canada He has recent
ly conversed with Captain Brandt-(a son OF the ce.
lebraed Brandt OF the revolution, aud highly res-
pectable man) who knows nothing about the affair
whatever Besides, il is not likely that he should,
as he does not reside at Fort George. but fifty miles
in the interior. Our informant also that
affairs are so situated at Fort George, that entrance
could not have been obtained for the purpose of
acting that or any other tragedy. Nor was II beliey-
ed in The neighbourhood of Fort George, that Nor
gan had ever been taken across the river, and the
whole matter was spoken very lightly OF among the


inhabitants there. A,the same time justice requires
US to admit that there is small coincidence be-
tween the above story and he testimony of Israel B.
Hail. given on The trial OF Sheldon and others al Ca
nandaigua 1t stated in the story above, that an at
empt was made at Fort George TO get some OF The
British officers to carry Morgan down hs 81 Law
renee, and put him on board British vessel. And
MIR. Hall testified that Cheeseboro said Morgan
was where Miller would not get hold OF him-tha
he avoided giving witness direct answers to his ques
ions, and witness thinks he said be guessed Nor
gan was OF might be board British ship :
There seems TO be no doubt of the fact that Nor
gan was traced 10 the buryng ground between Lew
ston and Fort Niagara; the carriage stopped there;
ard all afterwards is mystery. The ou ylng ground
is on the bank of the river, and within few hun
ded yards Of the Fort

full articles.article:
Ho,c 10 Kill fens Once 90 time, face,ious
Hhrrnan was travelling in the eastern part OF Eng
land ID becoming almos! destitute ot cash, he
objected considerable quantity OF mill dust, and
continued his Journey. Now came still evening
on" and Paddy ente,ed public house and called
Tor entertainment. During the evening he bus'ed
himself in tying his dust up in small papers, IN the
form Of powders On being lnterrogated by the
iandlady to know hot the papers contained, he re-
piled" Fla powthur. ma'am; for the purpose OF
killing fas.n The goodlady, whose house had been
so,ely besieged by these troublesome maranders,
was very anxious to obai" some OF the powders !;
and Paddy agreed for his lodging breakfast bitters
&c 10 furnish her with quantity sufficient to des-
troy all he f9s in it. H., accordingly was treated
with the greatest hospitality. and in The morning
(hay;ng left dozen or Of his powders,j he
slung his pack and with great sang trsd was about
to DEPART when his benevolent hostess called upon
him TO know in what manner she should apply The
| powder tPon me sowl, to be sure, was or the
| pon, of forgetting to give ye the directions Well,


then mind dive see, you must take the little era


chures by the nap o. the neck. and With leather
tickle their tails and when they open their mouths


10 laugh, Just throw in few grains OF the prwthur


and i, will be sure death forum III warrant ye-


Good morning ma'am!'
